{{nihongo|'''Fumio Kishida'''|岸田 文雄|Kishida Fumio|extra=born 29 July 1957
}} is a Japanese politician who has served as [[Prime Minister of Japan]] and [[President of the Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|President]] of the [[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|Liberal Democratic Party]] (LDP) since 2021. A member of the [[House of Representatives (Japan)|House of Representatives]], he previously served as [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Japan)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]] from 2012 to 2017 and as acting [[Minister of Defense (Japan)|Minister of Defense]] in 2017. From 2017 to 2020, he also chaired the LDP Policy Research Council.

Born into a political family, Kishida spent part of his childhood in the United States, where he attended elementary school in New York City. After beginning his career in finance, Kishida entered politics and was elected to the House of Representatives in [[1993 Japanese general election|1993]] as a member of the LDP. Kishida was appointed to various posts in the cabinets of prime ministers [[Shinzo Abe]] and [[Yasuo Fukuda]] from 2007 to 2008, and was appointed Minister for Foreign Affairs in 2012 after Abe regained the premiership following the [[2012 Japanese general election|2012 general election]], serving for five years and becoming the longest-serving Foreign Affairs Minister in Japanese history. Kishida resigned from the Abe cabinet in 2017 in order to head the LDP's Policy Research Council. Kishida also assumed leadership of the LDP's more moderate [[Kōchikai]] faction in 2012 following the retirement of faction leader [[Makoto Koga]], a position he held until his resignation in 2023. Long considered a potential future prime minister, Kishida ran in the [[2020 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|2020 LDP leadership election]], but lost to [[Yoshihide Suga]]. He ran again for the party leadership in [[2021 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|2021]], this time winning in a second round run-off against opponent [[Taro Kono]]. Kishida was confirmed as prime minister by the [[National Diet]] four days later on 4 October 2021.

As prime minister, Kishida has stated that his premiership will focus on a "new model of [[capitalism]]" by seeking to implement [[Redistribution of income and wealth|redistributive policies]] to expand the [[middle class]]. He led the LDP to victory in the [[2021 Japanese general election|2021 general election]] and the [[2022 Japanese House of Councillors election|2022 House of Councillors election]], albeit at a slightly reduced majority. He oversaw the dissolution of the [[Unification Church]] (UC) in Japan following the [[assassination of Shinzo Abe|assassination of former prime minister Shinzo Abe]] in 2022, the disbandment of his faction Kōchikai, along with [[Seiwa Seisaku Kenkyūkai|Seiwakai]] and [[Shisuikai]] following a [[2023–2024 Japanese slush fund scandal|party-wide corruption scandal]] and the [[Discharge of radioactive water of the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant|release of treated radioactive water from the Fukushima nuclear power plant]] into the Pacific Ocean in 2023. He [[Cabinet reshuffle|reshuffled]] his cabinet twice, in [[Second Kishida Cabinet (First Reshuffle)|August 2022]] to remove cabinet members affiliated with the UC and in [[Second Kishida Cabinet (Second Reshuffle)|September 2023]] following low approval ratings. On foreign policy, he has continued strengthening the [[Quadrilateral Security Dialogue|Quad Security Dialogue]] and close cooperation with [[NATO]] in pursuit of the [[Free and Open Indo-Pacific]] strategy, signed the [[American–Japanese–Korean trilateral pact]] in 2023, formed [[Defense pact|security pacts]] with the United Kingdom and Australia, taken steps to repair ties with South Korea and in 2022 instructed the cabinet to increase Japan's military budget by 65% by 2027. Kishida responded to the [[Russian invasion of Ukraine]] by becoming the first Asian country to impose [[International sanctions during the Russian invasion of Ukraine|sanctions on Russia and Belarus]] and authorizing civilian aid to Ukraine. He survived an [[Attempted assassination of Fumio Kishida|assassination attempt]] on 15 April 2023 while delivering a campaign speech.

== Early life and education ==
Kishida was born to a political family in [[Shibuya]], Tokyo, on 29 July 1957.<ref name="thediplomat1">{{cite web |last1=Akimoto |first1=Daisuke |date=7 September 2021 |title=The Arrival of Kishida Diplomacy? |url=https://thediplomat.com/2021/09/the-arrival-of-kishida-diplomacy/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210928162945/https://thediplomat.com/2021/09/the-arrival-of-kishida-diplomacy/ |archive-date=28 September 2021 |access-date=29 September 2021 |website=The Diplomat |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=kantei>{{cite web|title=Fumio Kishida|url=https://japan.kantei.go.jp/96_abe/meibo/daijin/kishida_e.html|publisher=Kantei|access-date=30 September 2021|archive-date=28 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210928163701/https://japan.kantei.go.jp/96_abe/meibo/daijin/kishida_e.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=jtimes>{{cite news|title=Abe Cabinet (Formed December 26, 2012)|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/cabinet-profiles/abe-cabinet-formed-december-26-2012|access-date=30 September 2021|newspaper=The Japan Times|archive-date=30 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210930134100/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/cabinet-profiles/abe-cabinet-formed-december-26-2012|url-status=live}}</ref> His father, Fumitake Kishida, was a government official in the [[Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry]] and director of The Small and Medium Enterprise Agency. Since the Kishida family was from [[Hiroshima]], the family returned there every summer. Many members of the Kishida family had died in the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|atomic bombing]] and Fumio grew up hearing stories from the atomic bomb survivors.<ref name="atomic1">{{cite book |last1=Kishida |first1=Fumio |date=2020 |publisher=Nikkei BP |isbn=978-4296106974 |script-title=ja:『核兵器のない世界へ 勇気ある平和国家の志』 |trans-title=Towards a World Without Nuclear Weapons: Ambition of a Courageous Peaceful Nation |chapter=第一章 故郷・広島への想い |trans-chapter=Chapter 1: Thoughts on my hometown, Hiroshima}}</ref> Both his father Fumitake and grandfather Masaki Kishida were former politicians who were members of the House of Representatives.<ref name="jtimes" /> Former [[Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry]] [[Yoichi Miyazawa]] is his cousin<ref name="yomiuri2020-09-09">{{Cite web |date=2020-09-13 |title=［自民党総裁選］岸田さんこんな人…「勝つまで戦う」酒豪 |url=https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/topics/20200909-OYT8T50012/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211004110126/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/topics/20200909-OYT8T50012/ |archive-date=4 October 2021 |access-date=2020-09-19 |website=Yomiuri Shimbun |language=ja}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|date=23 October 2014|title=Japan minister support staff 'put sex club on expenses'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-29735264|access-date=24 October 2014|publisher=[[BBC]]|archive-date=24 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024054943/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-29735264|url-status=live}}</ref> and former prime minister [[Kiichi Miyazawa]] is a distant relative.<ref name="jtimes" />

Kishida went to [[New York City Department of Education|P.S. 013 Clement C. Moore]] elementary school in the [[Elmhurst, Queens|Elmhurst]] neighborhood of [[Queens]], New York, because his father was posted to a job in the U.S. at the time.<ref name="next">{{Cite web |last=Landers |first=Peter |date=3 September 2021 |title=Japan's Next Prime Minister: Who Are the Candidates to Succeed Yoshihide Suga? |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/japans-next-prime-minister-who-are-the-candidates-to-succeed-yoshihide-suga-11630657293 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210928162940/https://www.wsj.com/articles/japans-next-prime-minister-who-are-the-candidates-to-succeed-yoshihide-suga-11630657293 |archive-date=28 September 2021 |access-date=28 September 2021 |website=Wall Street Journal |language=en-US}}</ref> He also attended Kōjimachi Elementary School and Kōjimachi Junior High School. Kishida graduated from [[Kaisei Academy]], where he played on the baseball team.<ref name="Straits">{{cite news |last=Sin |first=Walter |date=2 October 2021 |title=Fumio Kishida: Japan's ronin turned prime minister-designate |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/fumio-kishida-japans-ronin-turned-prime-minister-designate |work=[[The Straits Times]] |access-date=4 October 2021 |archive-date=3 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211003211726/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/fumio-kishida-japans-ronin-turned-prime-minister-designate |url-status=live }}</ref>

Following several rejections from the [[University of Tokyo]], Kishida studied law at [[Waseda University]] and graduated in 1982.<ref name="kantei" /><ref name="Straits" /> At Waseda, he was friends with future politician [[Takeshi Iwaya]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last1=Reynolds |first1 =Isabel |last2=Hirokawa |first2=Takashi |date=20 July 2017 |title=Abe's Low-Key Foreign Minister Watched as Potential Rival |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-20/abe-s-low-key-foreign-minister-emerges-as-key-rival-to-run-japan |language=en |work=Bloomberg.com |access-date=29 August 2020 |archive-date=29 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210929144248/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-20/abe-s-low-key-foreign-minister-emerges-as-key-rival-to-run-japan |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Fumio Kishida: calm centrist picked as Japan's next prime minister">{{cite news |agency=Agence France-Presse |title=Fumio Kishida: calm centrist picked as Japan's next prime minister |url=https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/1494663/fumio-kishida-calm-centrist-picked-as-japans-next-prime-minister |access-date=8 October 2021 |work=INQUIRER.net |date=29 September 2021 |language=en |archive-date=8 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211008164649/https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/1494663/fumio-kishida-calm-centrist-picked-as-japans-next-prime-minister |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Political career ==
[[File:PM Modi meets Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs Fumio Kishida, in Tokyo.jpg|thumb|left|Kishida with Indian Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]], September 2014]]

After working at now-defunct [[Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan]] and then as a secretary to a member of the House of Representatives, Kishida was elected to the House of Representatives in the [[1993 Japanese general election|1993 general election]], representing the Hiroshima 1st district.<ref name="asahi">{{cite news|title=Profiles of key ministers in Abe's new Cabinet|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/politics/AJ201212260086|access-date=27 December 2012|newspaper=The Asahi Shimbun|date=26 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705190313/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/politics/AJ201212260086|archive-date=5 July 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref>

Kishida served as Minister of Okinawa Affairs from 2007 to 2008, firstly in the Abe Cabinet and later in the Fukuda cabinet.<ref name="hofj">{{cite news|date=27 December 2012|title=Profile: Foreign Minister Kishida boasts background in Okinawa affairs|newspaper=House of Japan|url=http://www.houseofjapan.com/local/profile-foreign-minister-kishida-boasts-background-in-okinawa-affairs|url-status=dead|access-date=3 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202225149/http://www.houseofjapan.com/local/profile-foreign-minister-kishida-boasts-background-in-okinawa-affairs|archive-date=2 December 2013}}</ref> He was appointed state minister in charge of consumer affairs and food safety in the cabinet of then prime minister [[Yasuo Fukuda]] in 2008.<ref name="jtimes" /> Kishida was also state minister in charge of science and technology in the Fukuda cabinet.<ref name="hofj" />

He was close to [[Makoto Koga]], leader of the [[Kōchikai]] faction, one of the oldest inside the LDP, and assumed control of it in October 2012 after Makoto Koga announced his retirement from politics.<ref name="jtimes" />

=== Abe government ===
[[File:Визит Министра обороны России Министра иностранных дел в Токио.jpg|thumb|Kishida with Russian Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] and Russian Defense Minister [[Sergei Shoigu]] in March 2017|left]]
Following the LDP's victory in the [[2012 Japanese general election|2012 general election]], Kishida was named foreign minister in the Cabinet of Prime Minister [[Shinzō Abe]] on 26 December 2012.<ref name="asahi" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Abe elected premier, launches Cabinet|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T121226002018.htm|access-date=3 January 2013|newspaper=Daily Yomuiru Online|date=26 December 2012|archive-date=30 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121230194816/http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T121226002018.htm|url-status=live}}</ref> He became the longest-serving foreign minister in postwar history, surpassing Abe's father [[Shintaro Abe]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Bosack|first=Michael|date=9 July 2018|title=Will Kishida Challenge Abe's Leadership?|url=https://www.tokyoreview.net/2018/07/kishida-abe-leadership-challenge/|access-date=29 August 2020|website=Tokyo Review|archive-date=20 August 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200820065646/https://www.tokyoreview.net/2018/07/kishida-abe-leadership-challenge/|url-status=live}}</ref> He helped to arrange U.S. President [[Barack Obama]]'s historic visit to [[Hiroshima]] in May 2016, and gained attention in 2017 when he appeared alongside comedian [[Daimaou Kosaka|Piko Taro]] to promote a United Nations  program.<ref name=":0" />

He was not in favor of the appointment of [[Toshihiro Nikai]] as LDP secretary-general by Abe in 2016 against the wishes of Kishida's own faction, which was seen as an attempt at blocking generational change inside the LDP.<ref>{{Cite web|date=11 September 2021|title=Kishida goes all out for Japan's top job|url=https://www.eastasiaforum.org/2021/09/11/kishida-goes-all-out-for-japans-top-job/|access-date=28 September 2021|website=East Asia Forum|archive-date=28 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210928162941/https://www.eastasiaforum.org/2021/09/11/kishida-goes-all-out-for-japans-top-job/|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2017, Kishida left the Cabinet to take over the chairmanship of the LDP Policy Research Council, a position traditionally seen as a stepping stone to leadership of the party.<ref>{{Cite news|date=2 August 2017|title=Japanese Foreign Minister Kishida set to take key ruling party post: NHK|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-politics-idUSKBN1AI073|access-date=29 August 2020|archive-date=22 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200922185255/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-politics-idUSKBN1AI073|url-status=live}}</ref> He sought this position in order to improve his chances to succeed Abe, as the foreign minister post had relatively little influence within the party.<ref name=":1" />

Kishida considered running in the [[2018 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|2018 LDP presidential election]], but he was persuaded by Abe not to run, with a suggestion that Abe would later support Kishida as his successor.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Yoshida|first=Reiji|date=24 July 2018|title=LDP policy chief Fumio Kishida says he won't run in party leadership election, leaving two-way race between Abe and Ishiba|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/07/24/national/politics-diplomacy/ldp-policy-chief-fumio-kishida-says-wont-run-partys-election-leaving-two-way-race-abe-ishiba/|access-date=4 October 2021|website=The Japan Times|language=en-US|archive-date=4 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211004062900/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/07/24/national/politics-diplomacy/ldp-policy-chief-fumio-kishida-says-wont-run-partys-election-leaving-two-way-race-abe-ishiba/|url-status=live}}</ref> By mid-2020, several senior LDP lawmakers had shifted their support from Kishida to Chief Cabinet Secretary [[Yoshihide Suga]]. Deputy Prime Minister [[Tarō Asō|Taro Aso]] was also popular for sending stimulus payments to households during the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Japan|COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Sakaguchi|first=Yukihiro|date=26 June 2020|title=Race to replace Abe threatens stability of Japanese politics|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/Inside-Japanese-politics/Race-to-replace-Abe-threatens-stability-of-Japanese-politics|access-date=29 August 2020|website=Nikkei Asian Review|archive-date=28 August 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828215542/https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/Inside-Japanese-politics/Race-to-replace-Abe-threatens-stability-of-Japanese-politics|url-status=live}}</ref> Kishida ran in the [[2020 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|2020 LDP presidential election]] but lost out to Suga, who became prime minister;<ref>{{Cite web |title=Leading by listening: Kishida offers Japan a traditional style of politics |url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/The-Big-Story/Leading-by-listening-Kishida-offers-Japan-a-traditional-style-of-politics |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211031170238/https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/The-Big-Story/Leading-by-listening-Kishida-offers-Japan-a-traditional-style-of-politics |archive-date=31 October 2021 |access-date=31 October 2021}}</ref> Kishida was not offered a position in the Suga cabinet, although his faction obtained two cabinet seats.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bosack|first=Michael MacArthur|date=16 September 2020|title=Breaking down Suga's picks for his first Cabinet|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2020/09/16/commentary/japan-commentary/yoshihide-suga-cabinet-rundown/|access-date=16 September 2020|website=The Japan Times|archive-date=18 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200918052325/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2020/09/16/commentary/japan-commentary/yoshihide-suga-cabinet-rundown/|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Prime Minister of Japan (2021–present) ==
[[File:Election of Prime Minister of Japan 20211004 (1).jpg|thumb|250x250px|Kishida is elected by the [[National Diet|Diet]], 4 October 2021.]]
{{See also|2021 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|First Kishida Cabinet||}}
Following Yoshide Suga's announcement on 3 September 2021 that he would resign, following low approval ratings (at one point below 30%), and a new wave of COVID-19 infections, Kishida and [[Taro Kono]] of [[Factions in the Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|Shikōkai faction]] were in the lead to replace him.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Taro Kono tops Kyodo poll of LDP members as most fit to be Japan PM |url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2021/09/5a90bbf0185a-breaking-news-48-of-ldp-members-see-kono-as-most-fit-japan-pm-kyodo-poll.html |access-date=2023-02-18 |website=Kyodo News+}}</ref> Suga's decision to not seek re-election as head of the LDP triggered another [[2021 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|leadership election]] in September, just a little more than a year after the previous election in [[2020 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|2020]].  Throughout the race, Kono was heavily favored to win as he remained in first place among various LDP polls, and he received endorsements by Suga and others.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Auto |first=Hermes |date=2021-09-04 |title=Suga backs Kono, Abe picks Takaichi: Battle lines drawn in fight for Japan's top job |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/japan-pm-suga-to-back-vaccine-minister-kono-in-ldp-leadership-race-media |access-date=2023-02-18 |website=The Straits Times |language=en}}</ref>

On 29 September 2021, Kishida defeated [[Taro Kono]] in [[2021 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|a runoff vote to become the leader]] of the ruling [[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|Liberal Democratic Party]] (LDP) and replaced outgoing party leader [[Yoshihide Suga]]. He received a total of 257 votes (60.19%), from 249 parliamentary members and eight rank-and-file members, to become Japan's next prime minister.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ogura |first1=Junko |last2=Wang |first2=Selina |last3=Regan |first3=Helen |title=Fumio Kishida expected to become Japan's next Prime Minister after ruling party vote |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/29/asia/japan-leadership-election-kishida-intl-hnk/index.html |date=29 September 2021 |access-date=29 September 2021 |website=CNN |archive-date=29 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210929070431/https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/29/asia/japan-leadership-election-kishida-intl-hnk/index.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== 2021 general election and Second Cabinet ===
{{See also|2021 Japanese general election|Second Kishida Cabinet}}

and [[Nobuo Kishi]], who retained their respective posts from the [[Suga Cabinet|previous cabinet under Suga]];<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sim |first1=Walter |title=Who's who in Cabinet of Japan's new PM === Domestic policy ===

==== Economy ====
In December 2022, Kishida instructed his government to increase "national security-related spending" to 2 percent of Japan's GDP, while increasing the military budget from 5.4 trillion yen ($40 billion) in 2022 to 8.9 trillion yen ($66 billion) by 2027, up 65%. This would lead to a spending a total of around 43 trillion yen ($321 billion) between 2023 and 2027, up 56% from 2019 to 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Liff |first=Adam P. |date=22 May 2023 |title=No, Japan is not planning to "double its defense budget" |url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2023/05/22/no-japan-is-not-planning-to-double-its-defense-budget/ |access-date=23 May 2023 |website=[[Brookings Institution]]}}</ref>

Kishida appointed [[Kazuo Ueda]] as Governor of the [[Bank of Japan]] in April 2023, who stated he planned to continue the ultra easy monetary policy introduced by the outgoing Governor [[Haruhiko Kuroda]].<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Kihara |first1=Leika |last2=Kajimoto |first2=Tetsushi |date=2023-07-18 |title=BOJ's Ueda signals resolve to maintain ultra-easy policy |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/markets/asia/bojs-ueda-still-some-distance-sustainably-hit-2-inflation-target-2023-07-18/ |access-date=2023-09-16}}</ref> A few weeks before his [[Second Kishida Cabinet (Second Reshuffle)|next cabinet reshuffle]], Kishida stated he wanted to raise the hourly minimum wage in Japan to about ¥1,500 ($10.29) by 2030.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Nagata |first=Kazuaki |date=2023-09-11 |title=Economists question the wisdom of Kishida's new minimum wage target |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/business/2023/09/11/economy/new-minimum-wage-target/ |access-date=2023-09-16 |website=The Japan Times |language=en}}</ref>

==== Child care ====
Kishida set child care as his government's priority for the year 2023. He emphasized the potential consequences of child poverty and declining birth rates, and stated that his administration would increase monetary child benefits given to parents.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Takahara |first=Kanako |date=January 23, 2023 |title=In policy speech, Kishida puts focus on child care and defense |work=The Japan Times |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2023/01/23/national/politics-diplomacy/kishida-policy-speech-child-care-defense/ |url-status=dead |access-date=February 4, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230204231737/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2023/01/23/national/politics-diplomacy/kishida-policy-speech-child-care-defense/ |archive-date=4 February 2023}}</ref> Kishida announced a plan to double the country's children-related budget by June 2023, and instructed government ministers in the administration to outline child care plans by the end of March 2023.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Iizuka |first=Satoshi |date=January 24, 2023 |title=Japan PM Kishida's intention to raise sales tax in focus at Diet |work=Kyodo News |url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2023/01/53ef4c1af05b-focus-japan-pm-kishidas-intention-to-raise-sales-tax-in-focus-at-diet.html?phrase=foster%20care&words= |access-date=February 4, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=January 6, 2023 |title=Japan to Outline New Child Support Measures in March |work=Nippon.com |agency=Jiji Press |url=https://www.nippon.com/en/news/yjj2023010600387/ |url-status=dead |access-date=February 4, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230204231732/https://www.nippon.com/en/news/yjj2023010600387/ |archive-date=4 February 2023}}</ref>

Kishida established the [[:ja:こども家庭庁|Children and Families Agency]] on 1 April 2023 to serve as a new administrative body within the [[Cabinet Office (Japan)|Cabinet Office]] to tackle issues relating to child welfare.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-03-22 |title=Japan sets date for launch of new children's agency |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2023/03/22/national/children-families-agency-start-date/ |access-date=2024-01-01 |website=The Japan Times |language=en}}</ref>  This includes nursery access, child allowances, the fight against child poverty, child abuse and suicide prevention, cyberbullying, and support for children with disabilities, all of which had been handled by different government agencies.  On 1 June, the Japanese government set aside ¥3.5 trillion annually for child care.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Takahara |first=Kanako |date=2023-06-01 |title=Japanese government to set aside ¥3.5 trillion annually for child care |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2023/06/01/national/child-care-policy-budget/ |access-date=2023-06-06 |website=The Japan Times |language=en-US}}</ref>

==== Response to the COVID-19 Omicron variant ====
From 30 November 2021 to 7 May 2023, Japan has confirmed the first case of [[SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant|COVID-19 Omicron variant]], found from [[COVID-19 pandemic in South Africa|South Africa]]. An early Omicron cases were primarily imported until transmission began to develop.{{Citation needed|date=March 2022}}

In December 2021 amid Omicron variant spreading around the globe, Japanese Prime Minister Kishida announced that the government imposed tightening travel restrictions on international travelers, with some governments banning travel completely to curb transmission. By January 2022, Kishida urged Japanese people to get triple or fourth vaccinated amid the country enter the first wave of pre-dominant Omicron COVID-19 virus, although the new state of emergency and new restrictions were both highly unlikely to fight record surge as of now.{{Citation needed|date=March 2022}}

On 21 August 2022 amid the second Omicron infection surge, it was reported that Prime Minister Fumio Kishida had tested positive for COVID-19 Omicron variant and he has experiencing "very mild" symptoms. On 22 August, in an online interview with a news company, Prime Minister Kishida will perform his official duties (while in quarantine) via telework from the Prime Minister's official residence. However, he emphasized that "I will continue to work remotely while undergoing medical treatment. I will also attend Cabinet meetings online. I will do my best to avoid delays in national politics." After completing his recuperation period on 31 August as he recovered from Omicron variant, Kishida entered the Prime Minister's Office and then returned to face-to-face duties.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}

In September 2022, Japanese Prime Minister Kishida announced that [[Visa policy of Japan|visa requirement]]s from some countries would be waived from 11 October, in a move to reopen international travel after the pandemic border restrictions. Prior to the pandemic, Japan did not require tourist visas for 68 countries and regions.{{Citation needed|date=October 2022}}

On 20 January 2023 amid the third Omicron infection falls, Japanese Prime Minister Kishida announced that the government pledged to downgrade the legal status of COVID-19 to a Class 5 disease, the same level as a seasonal influenza, a move that would lead to a major shift in the pandemic border restrictions that have been in place for around three years. However, on 13 March, Kishida's government ended the request for citizens to wear [[Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic|face masks]] in public, a policy initiated to combat the spread of Omicron variant and its subsequent subvariants.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-03-13 |title=Masks stay put in Japan as 3-year request to wear them ends |url=https://apnews.com/article/japan-masks-covid-e169a3a5635d14a7e8f5673646083b60 |access-date=2023-03-14 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref> On 27 April, Kishida's [[Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare|Health Minister]] [[Katsunobu Katō]] announced that the government would downgrade the classification of COVID-19 to be on par with "seasonal flu" by midnight 8 May.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Japan to downgrade COVID-19 to flu level on May 8 |url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Coronavirus/Japan-to-downgrade-COVID-19-to-flu-level-on-May-8 |access-date=2023-05-03 |website=Nikkei Asia |language=en-GB |archive-date=6 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230506032827/https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Coronavirus/Japan-to-downgrade-COVID-19-to-flu-level-on-May-8 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Regarding COVID-19 measures, Kato said in a press conference that Omicron variant and its subsequent subvariants were cause of less severe disease and deaths (during the first 16-month period) than any previous strains, which indicate there is no need to worry about an increase of public health risks. As of result, daily announcements of COVID-19 Omicron cases will be officially ended so far. Although the public health reports will be simplified to weekly announcements based on information from designated medical institutions.

==== Russian invasion of Ukraine ====

[[File:20230321ukraine 13.jpg|thumb|Kishida inspecting the burial place in the city of [[Bucha massacre|Bucha]]]]On 24 February 2022, following the beginning of the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine|Russian invasion of Ukraine]], Kishida joined other leaders of the [[G7]] nations in imposing [[economic sanctions]] on Russia. Kishida had previously stated in May 2023 that "I am determined to face Kim Jong Un directly myself, without any preconditions," and settle the issue of the [[North Korean abductions of Japanese citizens]]. Hopes for the summit were buoyed by North Korean condolences after the [[2024 Noto earthquake]]. Such plans are considered to be highly controversial in South Korea, particularly with president [[Yoon Suk Yeol]], who has taken a hardline stance on North Korea compared to former president [[Moon Jae-in]]. === Assassination of Shinzo Abe and cabinet reshuffle ===

After the [[assassination of Shinzo Abe]] on 8 July 2022, Kishida condemned the assassination,<ref>{{Cite web |title='Absolutely unforgiveable': Japan PM Kishida strongly condemns shooting of Shinzo Abe |url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/asia/shinzo-abe-shooting-grave-condition-japan-pm-kishida-condemns-unforgiveable-2796271 |date=2022-07-08 |website=CNA |language=en |access-date=10 August 2022 |archive-date=22 January 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230122200516/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/asia/shinzo-abe-shooting-grave-condition-japan-pm-kishida-condemns-unforgiveable-2796271 |url-status=live }}</ref> but refused to suspend political campaigning so as to demonstrate that democracy would not be impeded by violence. He later blamed insufficient police protection for allowing the murder to occur.<ref>{{Cite web |first=Mari |last=Yamaguchi |title=Japan PM blames police for death of former leader Shinzo Abe |url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/japan-pm-blames-police-death-leader-shinzo-abe-86800698 |access-date=2022-07-14 |website=ABC News |archive-date=14 July 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220714104450/https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/japan-pm-blames-police-death-leader-shinzo-abe-86800698 |url-status=live }}</ref> Because of media reports on the ties between the LDP and the [[Unification Church]], a Korean cult accused of scamming Japanese followers (including the suspect's mother) out of much of their wealth, Kishida [[Second Kishida Cabinet (Reshuffled)|reshuffled his Cabinet]] on 10 August 2022, which included removing Abe's brother, [[Nobuo Kishi]], from the role of Minister of Defense.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Japan PM revamps Cabinet to reverse flagging public support |url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2022/08/ee92908726d4-japan-pm-to-reshuffle-cabinet-ldp-leadership-as-public-support-slips.html |date=2022-08-10 |website=Kyodo News |access-date=10 August 2022 |archive-date=22 January 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230122200519/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2022/08/ee92908726d4-japan-pm-to-reshuffle-cabinet-ldp-leadership-as-public-support-slips.html |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Taro Kono]] was made the Minister of Digital Affairs. While the majority of members of the LDP, including Shinzo Abe and Nobuo Kishi, were related to the church to various degrees, there were no evidences of Kishida having any direct tie with the church or any of its affiliated entities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/podcast/unification-church-kishida/ |title=Lycoris Revolt: The Church, the State and Kishida's headache |work=[[The Japan Times]] |date=2022-12-07 |access-date=2022-12-14 |archive-date=14 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221214064340/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/podcast/unification-church-kishida/ |url-status=live}}</ref> However, it was reported in the 1 September issue of ''[[Shūkan Bunshun]]'' that {{ill|Mineo Nakayama|ja|中山峰男}}, the president of a Kumamoto circle for backing Kishida's bid for the premiership, was also a chairperson of a Unification Church-affiliated group which was advocating for building the [[Japan-Korea Undersea Tunnel]]. Both Kishida and Nakayama denied any knowledge of the tunnel advocacy group being related to the Unification Church.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.co.jp/articles/0146b8d2f558a6f43c02e1475ee9c1dddd9980e6 |title=「憤り感じる」「学生に教会の勧誘が及ばないように」岸田総理の後援会長 崇城大・中山学長が会見 |work=[[Abema Times]] |date=2022-08-24 |access-date=2022-08-28 |language=ja |archive-date=5 September 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220905084318/https://news.yahoo.co.jp/articles/0146b8d2f558a6f43c02e1475ee9c1dddd9980e6 |url-status=live}}</ref>

On 4 December 2023, Kishida denied having knowledge about the involvement of [[Newt Gingrich]] and {{ill|Masayoshi Kajikuri|ja|梶栗正義}} with the Unification Church during a meeting in October 2019, arranged by Abe. On the other hand, Kajikuri is the chairman of numerous organizations associated with the church.<ref>{{Cite web
|url=https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20231204_09/

=== Assassination attempt ===
{{Main|Attempted assassination of Fumio Kishida}}
{{See also|2023 Japan by-elections}}[[File:Fumio Kishida's press conference the day after attacked (cropped).jpg|thumb|Kishida (the day after the attack) during a press conference|211x211px]]
On 15 April 2023, a man threw a cylindrical explosive device at Kishida shortly before he was due to make a campaign speech in [[Wakayama (city)|Wakayama]]. The device exploded after a short delay during which Kishida was evacuated from the scene unharmed. Ryuji Kimura, a 24-year-old man from Hyogo Prefecture, was arrested at the scene, with cameras showing him holding what appeared to be a second cylindrical object as he was tackled to the ground. The incident took place as Kishida was talking with a candidate of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party just before his scheduled speech. Kishida immediately left by car after the incident and continued with his stump speech elsewhere in the city. He stated at an event later in the day that "elections are a bedrock of democracy," adding that it was extremely unforgivable that such violence took place.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Japan PM Kishida unhurt after explosion during campaigning |url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2023/04/cd6c270d9b57-urgent-japan-pm-kishida-unhurt-after-smoke-bomb-thrown-during-stump-speech.html |access-date=2023-04-15 |website=Kyodo News |archive-date=15 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230415030308/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2023/04/cd6c270d9b57-urgent-japan-pm-kishida-unhurt-after-smoke-bomb-thrown-during-stump-speech.html |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |first1=Emi |last1=Jozuka |first2=Junko |last2=Ogura |date=2023-04-15 |title=Man arrested after explosion prompts evacuation of Japanese leader Fumio Kishida from speech venue |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/04/14/asia/kishida-evacuated-japan-explosion-intl-hnk/index.html |access-date=2023-04-15 |website=CNN |archive-date=15 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230415032851/https://www.cnn.com/2023/04/14/asia/kishida-evacuated-japan-explosion-intl-hnk/index.html |url-status=live}}</ref> Kimura was indicted by Wakayama prosecutors on 7 September 2023 for attempted murder, among other charges.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-09-06 |title=Man charged over attempt to assassinate Japanese prime minister |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/asia/japan/fumio-kishida-assassination-attempt-japan-b2406322.html |access-date=2023-09-08 |website=The Independent |archive-date=7 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230907022340/https://www.independent.co.uk/asia/japan/fumio-kishida-assassination-attempt-japan-b2406322.html |url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Funds scandal and Second Reshuffled Cabinet ===
{{main|2023–2024 Japanese slush fund scandal}}
After news leaked in December of a slush fund scandal involving several [[Seiwa Seisaku Kenkyūkai|Abe faction]] ministers and senior party leaders, including [[Yasutoshi Nishimura]] and [[Kōichi Hagiuda]], Kishida sacked several of his own ministers involved in the scandal, including Nishimura along with [[Hirokazu Matsuno]] and a group of other Abe faction members. Along with this, further members of the faction resigned from their posts in the House of Representatives. It is believed that the Abe faction hid away over 500 million yen worth of money over five years. === Nuclear policy ===
[[File:Fumio Kishida October 2017.jpg|thumb|Kishida delivering a speech in October 2017]]Kishida is in favor of retaining nuclear power technology, which he says should be considered as a clean energy option, while also calling for the establishment of a $90.7 billion university fund to further stimulate science and promotion of renewable energy.<ref name="asahi1" />

Being a representative from [[Hiroshima]], Kishida has consistently advocated for Japanese diplomacy to promote nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament within the framework of the [[Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty]] (NPT).<ref name="thediplomat1" /> In the wake of the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]], Kishida rejected former Prime Minister [[Shinzo Abe]]'s proposal for Japan to consider hosting U.S. nuclear weapons as a deterrent, calling it "unacceptable" given the country's stance of maintaining the [[Three Non-Nuclear Principles|three non-nuclear principles]].<ref>{{cite news |date=28 February 2022 |title=Kishida calls idea of Japan sharing nukes with U.S. 'unacceptable' |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2022/02/28/national/politics-diplomacy/kishida-nuclear-sharing-abe/ |url-status=live |access-date=4 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220304083739/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2022/02/28/national/politics-diplomacy/kishida-nuclear-sharing-abe/ |archive-date=4 March 2022}}</ref>
